unit_learning_outcomes.description: Apply random sampling concepts to make inferences about a population.
Use hypothesis testing approaches (including likelihood ratio tests, score tests and Wald tests) to carry out statistical tests in various contexts.
Evaluate the relevance of the principles of Bayesian inference in various contexts, and apply them to solve inference problems.
Analyse a range of statistical inference contexts and evaluate how the concept of likelihood and the principle of maximum likelihood estimation can be applied.
Use estimation principles (including unbiasedness, consistency and relative efficiency) to assess the performance of inference procedures.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: After the lecture and SGTA each week, students are required to read the lecture notes again for this week, and also to read other relevant sections of the reference materials, for consolidating the knowledge learned in the lecture.
Before the lectures and SGTA's each week, students are required to read the lecture notes and work on the SGTA exercises.

enrolment_rules.description: (20cp at 2000 level including (STAT272 or STAT2372 or STAT273 or STAT2173)) or [(STAT270 or STAT2170) and (COMP257 or COMP2200) and (admission to BIT or BAdvIT)]

assessments.description: Students are required to submit their assignments (pdf documents) before the due time. Students will submit their assignments via a link on iLearn.

data.description: This unit provides an introduction to likelihood-based statistical inference. After a brief discussion of the multivariable calculus concepts needed, students will study (multivariate) change of variable, the likelihood function and maximum likelihood estimation, using examples of distributions from 2000-level probability units. The theory of estimation and hypothesis testing will be discussed, including most powerful tests, large sample theory, the sufficiency principle, the likelihood ratio principle, and sequential probability ratio tests.
data.title: Statistical Inference

description: This unit provides an introduction to likelihood-based statistical inference. After a brief discussion of the multivariable calculus concepts needed, students will study (multivariate) change of variable, the likelihood function and maximum likelihood estimation, using examples of distributions from 2000-level probability units. The theory of estimation and hypothesis testing will be discussed, including most powerful tests, large sample theory, the sufficiency principle, the likelihood ratio principle, and sequential probability ratio tests.
title: Statistical Inference
